journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part J: Journal of Engineering Tribology

title-group.article-title: Frequency domain modeling of eddy current loss for magnetic thrust bearings

article-meta.aff: 1Key Laboratory of Network and Information Security, Engineering University of CAPF, Xi’an, People’s Republic of China
2Institute of Mechatronics and Information Systems, Xi’an Jiaotong University, Xi’an, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: MS Zhang, Key Laboratory of Network and Information Security, Engineering University of CAPF, Xi’an 710086, People’s Republic of China. Email: zms2099@163.com

abstract.p: The eddy current loss, produced in the solid stator and thrust disk by a time-dependent field, limits the operation performance of magnetic thrust bearings. Therefore, the accurate modeling of eddy current loss is essential for them. This article presents an analytical model to calculate the eddy current loss for a magnetic thrust bearing. After dividing the magnetic thrust bearing into several parts according to flux distributions, the eddy current loss expression for each iron part is proposed by solving one-dimensional diffusion equations and integrating power density over the volume. As the boundary condition of the magnetic field problem, the surface magnetic field intensity is confirmed by a fractional transfer function. Finally, the validity of this model is verified by finite element method analysis and experimental measurements. Based on the above analysis and research, this modeling method can be used as a reference for the eddy current loss calculation of nonlaminated actuators.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: With contact-free rotors, active magnetic bearings (AMBs) usually have much lower losses than rolling or oil bearings.1 However, winding loss and iron losses including hysteresis loss and eddy current loss are still inevitable in the operation of AMBs. For magnetic thrust bearings (MTBs), due to the nonlaminated structure and high frequency time-dependent field, the iron losses will be great in the stator and thrust disk, and the eddy current loss is dominant.2 Serious eddy current not only causes a decrease in magnetic force and phase lag between the coil current and the magnetic force, but also generates heat which makes a great impact on the performance of the system. Therefore, an accurate analytical model of eddy current loss for nonlaminated structures would be useful in the design process to confirm the effects of actuator geometric and material properties on operation performances.

Many researchers have focused on the development of the analysis methods for eddy current problem, including analytical, numerical, and experimental methods. However, most of them are only suitable for laminated structures. Certainly, some excellent analytical methods have been given out for nonlaminated structures. Fukata3 analyzed the dynamics of an MTB using a linear model in view of the effects of eddy current. The frequency characteristics of the magnetic flux for coil current showed the effects of eddy current on dynamics. However, the skin effect of flux distribution was ignored in the analysis process and some parameters of eddy current analysis must be obtained from experimental results. Feeley4 proposed a simple dynamic model of eddy current in a C-type nonlaminated magnetic actuator by two-dimensional magnetic field solution for an iron bar with a long rectangular cross-section. The model is a linear lumped parameter electromagnetic circuit model, which could be analogous to electric circuit modeling methods. So the dynamic effects of eddy current can be understood intuitively. It was a pity that the effect of air-gap on eddy current was ignored. Kucera and Ahrens5 divided an MTB into several elementary parts and derived the magnetic field solutions for two typical geometries (semi-infinite plate and semi-infinite cylinder). Then, the magnetic field solution for each elementary part was approximated by the solution of a semi-infinite plate. Finally, an analytical solution for the flux of the MTB was obtained and the model of eddy current loss was developed by equivalent impedance method. It was an excellent model for calculating eddy current loss, but one parameter of this model must be identified from experimental data. In addition, the surface magnetic field solution was considered to be invariable, but it was not correct. Based on the researches of Feely and Kucera, Zhu et al.6,7, and Sun et al.8 put forward an effective reluctance model which was fractional frequency-dependent and could be easily confirmed for each divided part in the flux path. At the same time, the dynamic current and displacement stiffness, two important parameters for the MTB, were defined and calculated using this excellent model. Tian et al.9 used this model to analyze the ripple current of the switching power amplifier for an MTB. Both of the frequency- and time-domain models for the ripple current were obtained. However, the eddy current loss was still left unanswered in these references.

All of these analytical methods for eddy current analysis were convenient to use in the nonlaminated actuator design, but the accuracy was limited as material nonlinearity and leakage were not considered. Furthermore, the eddy current caused by the motion of rotor was ignored. At the same time, all of these nonidealities were not included in the analytical method of this study as well. As an excellent numerical method, finite element method (FEM) analysis10–15 was used to cover these drawbacks. In order to verify the validity of the above two methods, some experimental investigations of eddy current effects were carried out. Allaire et al.16 tested the current stiffness for an MTB. The phase lag and decrease in magnitude of force/current transfer function were obvious because of the influence of eddy current, even if the test bandwidth was narrow. Tian et al.9 and Raoul et al.17 measured the coil ripple current of MTBs, and the measurement results showed that the gap sensitivity of coil impedance was obviously influenced by the eddy current effect.

In this article, as an extension of the previous work, the effective reluctance model presented by Zhu et al.7 will be used to determine the existing problem in Kucera and Ahrens’5 work. According to his statement, as the boundary condition of eddy current calculation for an MTB, the surface magnetic field intensity is considered to be unavailable because of the complex of geometry. However, it can be easily solved by the effective reluctance model.

First, an MTB is divided into six elementary parts according to the flux distribution, including four iron and two air-gap parts. Second, the frequency-dependent model of eddy current loss for each iron part is obtained by solving one-dimensional diffusion equations and integrating resistive power loss over the volume. Third, as the boundary condition of the magnetic field problem, the surface magnetic intensity influenced by the eddy current is confirmed by a fractional transfer function. Then, the total eddy current loss can be obtained from all iron parts. Finally, harmonic analysis on FEM analysis and experimental measurements is used to verify the validity of the model.

sec.title: Modeling
sec.p:
Figure 1 shows the cross-section of an MTB. Except for coil, the stator, air-gap, and thrust disk are divided into six elementary parts according to the flux distribution, as shown in Figure 2. If one-dimensional hypothesis is proposed, parts 2 and 5 just have radial flux component and parts 1, 3, 4, and 6 only have axial flux component. Therefore, one-dimensional Maxwell equations can be easily used for elementary geometry. Figure 1.
Cross-section of an MTB.
MTB: magnetic thrust bearings.
Figure 2.
Flux distribution of the MTB.
MTB: magnetic thrust bearings.

In order to simplify the analysis, some hypotheses are listed as follows:
hysteresis and leakage are ignored;
only linear and isotropic materials are considered; and
the flux distribution in air-gap is uniform.

sec.title: Modeling of eddy current loss in a harmonic field
sec.p: In MTBs, displacement current can be neglected, as the frequency of coil current is sufficiently low. At the same time, one-dimensional eddy current problems can be described by using diffusion equations.18 Kucera and Ahrens5 developed the distribution expressions of the magnetic field intensity for a rotational symmetric plate (such as part 2 or 5) and semi-infinite cylinder (such as part 4 or 6). Therefore, the formulas of the magnetic field distribution for parts 2, 4, 5, and 6, as shown in Figure 1 can be written as (1)H(2)r(r,z)=(eαz1+e-2αd+e-αz1+e2αd)H(2)sf (2)H(4)z(r)=I0(αr)I0(αr1)H(4)sf (3)H(5)r(r,z)=(eαz1+e2αh1+e-αz1+e-2αh1)H(5)sf (4)H(6)z(r)=K1(αr3)I0(αr)+I1(αr3)K0(αr)K0(αr2)I1(αr3)+I0(αr2)K1(αr3)H(6)sf in which α=(1+j)/δ and δ=2/ωμσ is the skin depth, ω the angular frequency of the coil current, μ and σ the permeability and conductivity of iron material, respectively, In(αr) and Kn(αr) the modified Bessel function of first and second types and n order, and H(k)sf the surface magnetic field intensity for part k, which will be discussed later.

According to Ampere’s law, ∇×H=J (H and J are magnetic field intensity and eddy current density), the eddy current density for each iron part can be obtained by differential operations (5)J(2)ϕ(r,z)=(αeαz1+e-2αd-αe-αz1+e2αd)H(2)sf (6)J(4)ϕ(r)=-αI1(αr)I0(αr1)H(4)sf (7)J(5)ϕ(r,z)=(αeαz1+e2αh1-αe-αz1+e-2αh1)H(5)sf (8)J(6)ϕ(r)=αI1(αr3)K1(αr)-αK1(αr3)I1(αr)K0(αr2)I1(αr3)+I0(αr2)K1(αr3)H(6)sf

For modified Bessel function In(x) and Kn(x), if the complex variable x>>|n2-1/4|, their simple asymptotic expressions19 can be obtained as (9)I0(x)≈I1(x)≈12πxex where -π2<arg(x)<π2. (10)K0(x)≈K1(x)≈x2πe-x where -π<arg(x)<π.

It can be obtained from Appendix 2 that the complex variable of the modified Bessel function in formulas (6) and (8) is large enough for fulfilling x>>|n2-1/4|. Under the use of these approximations, the simpler expressions will make them easy for mathematical operations.
In order to calculate the eddy current loss for each iron part, the power density is introduced (11)p=|J|2σ

Based on formula (11), the volume integral for each iron part in cylindrical coordinate system is performed and the model of eddy current loss for each part can be obtained as (12)P(2)=π|H(2)sf|2σδ(1-e-4d/δ-2e-2d/δsin(2dδ)) (r32-r02) (13)P(4)=2π|H(4)sf|2r1σδ(1-e-2(r1-r0)δ)h2 (14)P(5)=π|H(5)sf|2σδ(1-e-4h1/δ-2e-2h1/δsin(2h1δ)) (r22-r12) (15)P(6)=2π|H(6)sf|2r2σδ(1-e-4(r3-r2)/δ-2e-2(r3-r2)/δ sin(2(r3-r2)δ))h2

Because the eddy current loss is just produced in iron parts, parts 1 and 3 have no contributions to the eddy current loss, and the total eddy current loss model of the MTB can be expressed as (16)Pe=P(2)+P(4)+P(5)+P(6)

The surface magnetic field intensity that has been considered to be invariable because of the complex calculation of coil inductances5 will be changed due to the eddy current induced. Next, the concept of effective reluctance6–9 will be introduced to solve this problem.

sec.title: Surface magnetic field intensity
sec.p: When ampere circuital law is used for the surface (near to the coil) of the stator and thrust disk, it can be expressed as (17)∮H·dl=Hsf(s)·liron+Hair(s)·2g0=NI(s) where liron is the length of the iron surface; Hair(s) the air-gap magnetic field intensity; g0 the nominal length of the air-gap; N the number of the coil turns; I(s) the current of the coil, and s the complex frequency variable (s=2πfj for a harmonic field with frequency of f Hertz).

The previous studies7 demonstrate that the magnetic flux will decrease because of the influence of eddy current which will cause a reduction of air-gap magnetic field intensity. At the same time, the surface magnetic field intensities of the stator and thrust disk, as the boundary condition of magnetic field problem, will increase with the reduction of air-gap magnetic field intensity according to formula (17), so the air-gap magnetic field intensity must be confirmed first.

After introducing the effective reluctance7,9 into the model of the MTB, the effects of eddy current on the magnetic field distribution can be solved by magnetic circuit method similar to electric circuit method.

According to the above hypotheses and geometry division, the magnetic circuit is shown as Figure 3. Moreover, the effective reluctance for each part can be expressed as (18)ℜ=ℜr+ℜijω in which ℜ is the total effective reluctance; ℜr the static reluctance, and ℜi the coefficient of dynamic reluctance. Figure 3.
Magnetic circuit of the MTB.
MTB: magnetic thrust bearings.

In order to take fringing into consideration, the effective area20 of the air-gap for the MTB can be given out (19)Aeff=A0(1+kgg) in which kg=π2A0(r0+r1+r2+r3) and A0 are the nominal area of the air-gap.

Table 1 shows the expressions of ℜr and ℜi of each part for the MTB, which can be easily used for the magnetic circuit shown in Figure 3. So the magnetic flux Φ(s) in the flux path can be described as (20)Φ(s)=NI(s)ℜ Table 1.
Effective reluctance of the MTB.7–9
Static reluctance (ℜr) Dynamic reluctance (ℜi)
1 g/[μ0Aeff] 0
2 ln(r3/r0)/(2πμ0μrd) ln(r3/r0)/(2π)·σ/(μ0μr)
3 g/[μ0Aeff] 0
4 h1/[πμ0μr(r12-r02)] h1/(2πr1)·σ/(μ0μr)
5 ln(r2/r1)/(2πμ0μrh2) ln(r2/r1)/(2π)·σ/(μ0μr)
6 h1/[πμ0μr(r32-r22)] h1/(2πr2)·σ/(μ0μr)
MTB: magnetic thrust bearings.
Therefore, the air-gap magnetic field intensity can be written as (21)Hair(s)=NI(s)ℜAeffμ0 in which μ0 is the permeability of free space.
Substituting equation (18) into (21), the fractional transfer function of the MTB with input I(s) and output Hair(s) can be described as (22)Hair(s)I(s)=NAeffμ0(ℜr+ℜis)

Under the frequency response of this fractional transfer function, the air-gap magnetic field intensity at different frequencies can be easily obtained. Finally, the surface magnetic field intensity can also be calculated with Hair(s) (23)Hsf(s)=NI(s)-Hair(s)·2g0liron
Thus, the surface magnetic field intensity for each iron part in formulas (12) to (15) has the following relationship (24)H(2)sfl2+H(4)sfl4+H(5)sfl5+H(6)sfl6=Hsfliron
If the same material is used for the stator and thrust disk, the surface magnetic field intensity will be equal in value. (25)H(2)sf=H(4)sf=H(5)sf=H(6)sf=Hsf
Now, all of the parameters needing to be calculated eddy current loss with equations (12) to (15) are known. The total eddy current loss of the MTB shown in (16) is finally determined.

sec.title: Simulation
sec.p: As an excellent numerical method for electromagnetic calculations, FEM analysis considers the material nonlinearity and leakage. In this part, compared with the analytical method studied above, the eddy current loss of the MTB is researched with FEM analysis.

As a simplification, the thrust disk is assumed to be concentric with the stator, so a two-dimensional axisymmetric FEM model can be established and the FEM software ANSYS 10.0 can be used for the analysis.

Figure 4 shows the coupled circuit and magnetic field model of the MTB. An independent current source, two resistors and a stranded coil current source are used in the electric circuit. Regions A1, A2, and A4 represent the coil, stator, and thrust disk; A3, A5, A7, and A9 represent the surrounding air; A6 and A8 represent the air-gap. The FEM calculation model is shown in Figure 5. Except for four elements and four nodes used for the electric circuit, there are a total of 4649 elements and 9646 nodes used. In order to improve the accuracy of the calculation at high frequency, finer mesh is used in the region near the surface of the stator and thrust disk. In these areas, the skin effect is getting more and more serious with higher frequency. Then, the current and EMF freedom of electric and magnetic elements are coupled together. Finally, the parallel flux boundary condition is applied to the outer boundary (L1–L8) of the calculation region. Therefore, no flux lines will cross over this boundary. Figure 4.
Electromagnetic-circuit coupled FEM model.
FEM: finite element method.
Figure 5.
Mesh of the FEM model.
FEM: finite element method.

Finally, the harmonic analysis is performed by FEM method, but the hysteresis effect is ignored. The parameters of the calculated MTB are given in Tables 2 and 3. Table 2.
Dimensions of the test MTB.
Item Value (mm) Item Value (mm)
Inner radius of the bearing (r0) 50.0 Thickness of the back iron (h1) 5.0
Inner radius of the slot (r1) 55.0 Length of the slot (h2) 15.0
Outer radius of the slot (r2) 68.0 Thickness of the thrust disk (d) 10.0
Outer radius of the bearing (r3) 72.0 Nominal thickness of the air-gap (g0) 0.5
MTB: magnetic thrust bearings.
Table 3.
Parameters of the test MTB.
Item Value Item Value
Relative permeability of 40CrNiMnA (μr) 650 Resistivity of 40CrNiMnA (ρ) 1.00×10-7Ω·m
Amplitude of the coil current (I0) 0.5 A Resistivity of the coil (ρc) 2.55×10-8Ω·m
Resistance of the coil (R) 0.8Ω Nominal area of the flux path (A0) 1704mm2
The number of the coil turns (N) 86 Equivalent length of the flux path (liron) 89 mm
MTB: magnetic thrust bearings.

sec.title: Experimental
sec.p:
In order to verify the analytical model and the results of FEM analysis, an MTB experimental setup shown in Figure 6 was used to measure the eddy current loss. In the experimental setup, the thrust disk was supported by a horizontal stand and the rotor was kept in vertical position. At the same time, the air-gap length between the stator and thrust disk was kept to be 0.5 mm by sheets of paper. It is known that the permeability of the paper equals that of the vacuum. Figure 6.
Configuration of the experimental setup.

The experiment scheme is shown in Figure 7 and the measurement equipments were used as follows:
LEM Norma 5000 power analyzer permitting to analyze the electrical parameters of actuators.
Current probe AGILENT N2782A. The measurement range is 30 A and the sample frequency is 50 MHz.
Tektronix AFG 3022 dual channel arbitrary/function generator.
Linear power amplifier APEX MP108FD for high voltage or current applications.
GW INSTEK sps-606 DC power supply 60 V/6A.
Figure 7.
Experiment scheme.

Generally, the MTBs are driven by switching the amplifier containing high frequency ripple current, which makes the previous harmonic analysis unable to be verified accurately. As a substitute, the coil of the MTB was driven by a linear power amplifier, and the current was regulated by a signal generator. It is known that the coil impedance will be influenced by the time-varying magnetic field caused by eddy current and hysteresis. The consumptive energy of eddy current loss and hysteresis loss can be reflected in the change of coil impedance. Therefore, the power losses containing winding loss, hysteresis loss, and eddy current loss can be analyzed with a power analyzer by measuring the coil current and voltage between the two ends of the coil. It is obvious that the component of eddy current loss is the key in this test. So the winding loss and hysteresis loss should be separated from the results, respectively. It is generally known that the winding loss can be easily determined by Joule’s law (26)Pw=I2R in which R is the static resistance of the coil. Unfortunately, the hysteresis loss has to be ignored because it was smaller and difficult to separate.
The parameters of the MTB are given in Tables 2 and 3. The material used for the stator and thrust disk is 40CrNiMnA.

sec.title: Results and discussions
sec.p:
The frequency responses of air-gap magnetic field intensity derived from the results of FEM analysis and the fractional transfer function are shown in Figure 8. With the decrease of the air-gap magnetic field intensity, the amplitude of the surface magnetic field intensity of the stator and thrust disk will increase according to Ampere’s circuital law, as shown in Figure 9. In addition, the control magnetic force will be weakened with the decrease of air-gap magnetic field intensity. As a result, the overall system stability must be influenced by eddy current, which has been discussed in detail by Kim.21 Figure 8.
Frequency response of the air-gap magnetic field intensity.
Figure 9.
The amplitude of the surface magnetic field intensity at different frequencies.

It can be seen that the differences in the results of the two methods are mainly at the high frequency region because of the material nonlinearity and leakage effects. The maximum differences in the magnitude and phase of air-gap magnetic field intensity are only 1 dB and 2° at 10 kHz. Thus, the analytical model could well incorporate the effects of the eddy current and give a good result in loss calculation.

The measured and calculated results of the eddy current loss at different frequencies are shown in Figure 10. The winding loss has been subtracted from the measured and FEM analysis results. It can be shown that both of the analytical method and FEM analysis show a good validity for eddy current loss calculation. Compared with the experimental results, the maximum differences in the FEM results and analytical results are 7% and 1%, respectively. However, the FEM analysis results should be closer to the measured results than the analytical method because the material nonlinearity and leakage are considered in the FEM analysis, but it is not reflected in Figure 10. It can be explained by the hysteresis loss, which is ignored by FEM analysis and analytical method. In addition, the analytical result is bigger than FEM result because of the material nonlinearity and leakage effects has been ignored. Figure 10.
The eddy current loss at different frequencies.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study presents an analytical model of eddy current loss for an MTB based on Maxwell equations and effective reluctance. As the boundary condition of the magnetic field problem, the surface magnetic field intensity is derived by the effective reluctance method. It is used to calculate magnetic field distribution and eddy current loss in consideration of the skin effect of eddy current. At the same time, the results of FEM analysis and experiments verify the validity of the analytical model.

Several principles for MTB design can be derived from this study.
Eddy current loss is proportional to |Hsf|2, the skin depth δ and some other structure parameters.
The surface magnetic field intensity is seriously influenced by eddy current.
In addition, other effects, such as hysteresis, material nonlinearity and leakage, also need to be considered for a more accurate model in the future work.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: The work described in this paper was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No. 11102144) and Shaanxi Provincial Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No. 2011JM1005).

sec.title: Appendix 2
sec.p: This appendix aims to clarify why the complex variable of the modified Bessel function in formulas (6) and (8) can fulfill x>>|n2-1/4|, which makes the complicated modified Bessel function able to be approximated by simple asymptotic expressions.

If we review the formulas (6) and (8) as following (27)J(4)ϕ(r)=-αI1(αr)I0(αr1)H(4)sf (28)J(6)ϕ(r)=αI1(αr3)K1(αr)-αK1(αr3)I1(αr)K0(αr2)I1(αr3)+I0(αr2)K1(αr3)H(6)sf it is obvious that the complex variables of the modified Bessel functions In(x) and Kn(x) just have relations with α and radial dimensions (r0, r1, r2, and r3), as shown in Figure 1. Therefore, we will pay more attention to the value of α at different frequencies.

As previously mentioned (29)α=(1+j)/δ (30)δ=2/ωμσ in which the iron permeability μ=μrμ0, the vacuum permeability μ0=4π×10-7H/m and the relative permeability of iron can be obtained from Table 3. The iron conductivity σ can be determined by the reciprocal of iron resistivity (ρ=1.00×10-7Ω×m). Finally, the absolute value of α at different frequencies can be easily obtained as Table 4. Table 4.
Absolute value of α at different frequencies.
Frequency (f=ω/2π)1 Hz10 Hz100 Hz1 kHz10 kHz
Absolute value of α 227 716 2265 7164 22,654

The minimum value of the radial dimension for the MTB is r0=0.05m, so the minimum absolute value of the variable x in the modified Bessel functions In(x) and Kn(x) at different frequencies can be obtained as Table 5. Table 5.
Absolute value of x at different frequencies.
Frequency (f=ω/2π)1 Hz10 Hz100 Hz1 kHz10 kHz
Absolute value of x 11.3 35.8 113.3 358.2 1132.7
It is obvious that the absolute value of x is far larger than the threshold |n2-1/4| which can be 0.25 or 0.75 when n equals 0 or 1, respectively.
